definition: Bitcoin is a decentralized digital money system. Transactions are recorded on a blockchain without a central authority.
tip: For larger amounts: hardware wallet + offline seed backup.

definition: A distributed ledger of blocks. Each block references the previous one cryptographically, making tampering difficult.
tip: Transactions are generally irreversible—double-check everything.

definition: A data package in a blockchain that bundles transactions and includes the previous block’s hash.
A cryptographic fingerprint of data. Tiny changes produce a completely different hash.
Software that validates blocks/transactions and enforces network rules.
Process where miners perform work to find blocks and earn rewards (Proof of Work).
Consensus mechanism where computational work secures the network (e.g., Bitcoin).
Consensus mechanism where validators lock capital (stake) to propose/validate blocks.
tip: PoS reduces energy use but has different centralization trade-offs.

definition: Event where the block subsidy is cut roughly every four years.
Queue of unconfirmed transactions waiting to be included in a block.
Fee that incentivizes miners. In Bitcoin, typically based on transaction size (bytes), not value.
Unspent Transaction Output: the spendable “chunks” that become inputs for new transactions.
Number of blocks added after your transaction (a safety measure).
tip: For large amounts: wait for more confirmations.

definition: Software/hardware that manages keys and signs transactions. Coins live on the blockchain.
Wallet connected to the internet (mobile/desktop). Convenient but riskier.
tip: Keep only spending amounts.

definition: Keys are kept offline (hardware wallet, offline backup).
tip: Backup strategy is critical.

definition: A dedicated device that isolates private keys and signs transactions securely.
tip: Buy directly from the manufacturer or authorized sellers.

definition: Word list used to restore a wallet. Anyone who has it controls your funds.
tip: Never photograph, never cloud-store, never share.

definition: Extra protection on top of the seed phrase. Without it, the wallet cannot be restored.
Secret key used to sign transactions—effectively control over funds.
Public key from which addresses can be derived.
Receiving address for transactions. Publicly visible on-chain.
Two-factor authentication (e.g., authenticator app). Improves account security.
tip: Prefer app/hardware over SMS.

definition: Wallet setup requiring multiple keys (e.g., 2-of-3) to spend funds.
tip: Great for teams/high-value storage.

definition: Know Your Customer: identity verification many exchanges must perform.
Anti Money Laundering: compliance measures to prevent money laundering.
Centralized exchange to buy/sell/trade. Custody often sits with the provider.
tip: For long-term holdings, consider self-custody (not your keys...).

definition: Decentralized exchange: trading via smart contracts without centralized custody.
tip: Verify token contract address (scam protection).

definition: Order executed at the current market price. Fast but can suffer slippage.
Order executes only at your specified price or better.
Order that triggers at a price level to limit downside.
Difference between bid and ask price.
Difference between expected and actual execution price, often due to volatility/liquidity.
How easily an asset can be traded without significantly moving the price.
Market capitalization: price per coin × circulating supply.
Amount of coins currently circulating in the market.
Maximum possible supply (e.g., BTC: 21 million).
Degree of price fluctuation over time.
Token designed to track a reference value (e.g., USD), either fiat- or crypto-backed.
tip: Stablecoins carry issuer and depeg risks.

definition: When a stablecoin loses its intended peg (e.g., $1).
Code on a blockchain that automatically executes rules (tokens, DeFi, NFTs).
tip: Bugs happen—audits help but are not a guarantee.

definition: Blockchain platform for smart contracts, DeFi, and NFTs.
Ethereum Virtual Machine: runtime for smart contracts on EVM-compatible chains.
Unit/fee mechanism for executing transactions and smart contract operations.
Fee calculated as gas price × gas limit.
Common gas price unit (1 Gwei = 10^-9 ETH).
Standard for fungible tokens on Ethereum/EVM.
Standard for non-fungible tokens (NFTs).
Non-Fungible Token: a unique token representing digital ownership/uniqueness.
Base blockchain layer (e.g., Bitcoin, Ethereum).
Scaling layer built on L1 (e.g., Lightning, rollups) to reduce fees and improve speed.
Bitcoin Layer-2 payment network enabling fast, low-fee off-chain payments.
L2 technique that batches many transactions and settles compressed data back to L1 (Optimistic/ZK).
Mechanism to move assets between blockchains.
tip: Bridges are common attack targets—be extra cautious.

definition: Service that feeds external data (e.g., prices) into smart contracts.
tip: Oracle failures can trigger liquidations.

definition: Decentralized finance applications (DEX, lending, derivatives) built on smart contracts.
Providing loans via protocols, typically backed by collateral.
Borrowing assets by depositing collateral.
Assets posted as security. If value drops, liquidation can occur.
Automatic closing of a position when collateral becomes insufficient.
Annual Percentage Yield: estimated yearly return including compounding (variable).
tip: High APYs often mean high risk.

definition: Total Value Locked: total value deposited in a protocol.
Automated Market Maker: DEX mechanism using liquidity pools rather than order books.
Pool of tokens that enables trading. Liquidity providers earn fees.
Token representing your share of a liquidity pool.
Relative underperformance vs holding when pool asset prices diverge.
Scam where project operators drain liquidity/assets and disappear.
tip: Red flags: anonymous team, no audits, aggressive promises.

definition: Fake sites/links used to steal seeds, keys, or logins.
tip: Verify URLs, never enter seed, use bookmarks.

definition: Malicious token/DApp approvals that later drain wallet funds.
tip: Review and revoke approvals regularly.

definition: Fake airdrops lure you into signing approvals or sharing your seed.
Tiny “dust” transfers used for deanonymization/tracking or as scam bait.
Malware that encrypts data and demands payment—often in crypto.
You hold your own keys. Full control, full responsibility.

term: Not your keys, not your coins
definition: If you don’t control the keys (e.g., exchange custody), you don’t fully control the coins.
Exchange feature: withdrawals only to approved addresses.
Chain reorganization when an alternative longer chain temporarily becomes canonical.
Point at which a transaction is considered practically irreversible (chain/consensus dependent).
Blockchain rule change or split (soft fork / hard fork).
Non-backward-compatible rule change that can split the chain.
Backward-compatible rule tightening (older nodes may still accept blocks).
Attack using similar-looking addresses to trigger copy/paste mistakes.
tip: Check the first/last characters every time.

definition: Actions that occur directly on the blockchain (transparent, traceable).
Actions outside the blockchain (e.g., Lightning channels, exchange ledgers).
Wallet where a provider holds the keys (e.g., exchange account).
Wallet where you control the keys yourself.
Tool that routes trades across multiple DEXs to find better pricing/slippage.
Exploiting transaction ordering to extract profit (e.g., sandwich attacks).
tip: Keep slippage low; aggregators/private RPC can help.

definition: Methods to limit losses (position sizing, stops, diversification).
Do Your Own Research: verify before you trade/invest.
Fear Of Missing Out: often leads to impulsive buying.
Fear, Uncertainty, Doubt: negative sentiment/news cycles.
Token economics (supply, emissions, utility, distribution, locks).
Token release schedule for teams/investors. Large unlocks can impact price.
Moment when locked tokens become transferable/tradable.
Locking pool liquidity for a period to reduce rug-pull risk (not a guarantee).
Legal frameworks (KYC/AML, taxes, etc.) vary by country.
tip: Use official sources/professional advice for decisions.

definition: Application-Specific Integrated Circuit: specialized hardware optimized for a specific algorithm, often used for mining.
tip: Consider electricity costs/ROI and buy only from reputable sellers (scam risk).

definition: A security principle where a system is physically isolated from the internet to prevent network-based attacks.
tip: Only connect offline devices using verified media.

definition: Distribution of free tokens to users, often for marketing or to reward early activity.
tip: Beware: many airdrops are scams—never enter your seed phrase.

definition: Algorithmic trading: buy/sell orders are executed automatically based on predefined rules.
tip: Backtesting and risk limits are essential—avoid overfitting.

definition: A general term for cryptocurrencies other than Bitcoin.
tip: Altcoins are often more volatile than BTC—size positions accordingly.

definition: The highest price an asset has ever reached (historical high).
tip: ATH doesn’t mean it must keep rising—plan for pullbacks.

definition: The lowest price an asset has ever reached (historical low).
Annual Percentage Rate: yearly interest without compounding (simple interest).
tip: APR is not APY—APY includes compounding.

definition: Exploiting price differences of the same asset across markets/exchanges by buying and selling.
tip: Fees, slippage, and transfer times can wipe out profits.

definition: Token standard of the BNB Beacon Chain (formerly Binance Chain) defining how tokens work in that ecosystem.
Token standard of the BNB Smart Chain (BSC), similar to ERC-20 but for the BSC ecosystem.
A market participant who expects prices to fall or positions for downside.
A market participant who expects prices to rise or positions for upside.
A false downward move that triggers short signals before price reverses upward.
tip: Wait for confirmation (structure/volume), don’t trade a single candle.

definition: An online tool to look up transactions, addresses, and blocks publicly on a blockchain.
tip: For transfers, verify the txid and recipient address.

definition: Reward for miners producing blocks, typically consisting of block subsidy plus transaction fees.
The mechanism a network uses to agree on the valid state of the blockchain (e.g., PoW, PoS).
Mathematical methods to protect data (e.g., signatures, hashing, encryption).
tip: Security often depends more on key protection than on math.

definition: A measure of how hard it is to find a valid block. It adjusts based on network hashrate.
Distributed Denial of Service: many devices flood a service with requests until it becomes unavailable.
A distributed ledger replicated and synchronized across multiple participants (a core principle of many blockchains).
A historical term for Ethereum’s move to Proof of Stake and subsequent upgrades. Today it’s more commonly referred to as “Ethereum upgrades”.
Government-issued currency (e.g., EUR, USD) that isn’t necessarily backed by a commodity.
A derivative that tracks an asset’s price (long/short), often traded with leverage.
tip: Leverage increases liquidation risk—use strict risk management.

definition: Blockchain gaming that combines gameplay with tokens/NFTs and DeFi-like mechanics.
Crypto slang for long-term holding (“hold on for dear life”).
tip: Define a plan: horizon, risk, rebalancing.

definition: Initial Coin Offering: a token sale used to fund a project, often before product maturity.
tip: High risk—check team, vesting, utility, and tokenomics.

definition: Initial Exchange Offering: a token sale conducted via an exchange.
Joy Of Missing Out: being glad you skipped an opportunity that later proved risky or wrong.
A term for someone who owns no cryptocurrencies.
An electronic list of open buy and sell orders on an exchange (bid/ask).
Direct trading between two parties without a public order book, often used for large trades.
A physical printout/note of keys or QR codes. Historically used, but error-prone today.
tip: Prefer hardware wallets plus proper offline backups.

definition: Manipulation where an asset is artificially pumped up and then dumped/sold off.
tip: Red flags: guaranteed profits, thin liquidity, hype groups.

definition: A machine-readable code that can store wallet addresses or payment requests.
A project plan outlining milestones and expected releases.
tip: Roadmaps are marketing—verify delivery history and execution.

definition: A wallet app on desktop/laptop/phone. Convenient but dependent on device security.
tip: Keep devices secure (updates, avoid shady downloads).

definition: A scaling concept that splits data/load across multiple shards to increase throughput.
A hash algorithm used by Bitcoin and others to fingerprint data cryptographically.
Locking or delegating coins to help secure a network/protocol and earn rewards.
tip: Watch for lockups, slashing risk, and smart-contract risk.

definition: A blockchain test environment for development and experiments without real funds.
Permanently removing tokens from circulation (e.g., sending to a burn address).
A token intended to provide access to features/services of a platform—typically not an equity share.
A Proof-of-Stake participant who validates blocks/transactions and earns rewards.
An entity with very large holdings that can move markets with large orders.
A document explaining a project’s purpose, technology, tokenomics, and roadmap.
tip: Look for concrete mechanics, not just buzzwords.

definition: Strategies that move capital across protocols to maximize interest/rewards.
tip: Risks: smart contracts, impermanent loss, token inflation.

definition: A transaction not yet included in a block (0 confirmations).
tip: Do not treat as final for larger amounts.

definition: A cryptographic method to prove something without revealing the underlying data (key for ZK rollups/privacy tech).
